intro.p: "I think I'm finally getting inverse functions," {{stu}} tells you in the tutoring lab. "But I found this exercise in the textbook that got a little messy. It's an even-numbered problem so the answer isn't in the back of the book. Is it right?"
The problem reads: Determine the inverse function, if it exists, for: \displaystyle f(x) = {{f}}.
"I got this answer," {{stu}} says, pointing on {{pos}} paper where {{pn}} wrote:
"But that doesn't look right... it looks too much like the original function. That can't be right, can it?" {{pn}} ask{{suf}}.

content.p: Demonstrate how {{stu}} can check {{pos}} answer to determine whether this g is the inverse function to f, without simply solving the problem from the beginning.

Explain in writing the steps you're taking and how they tell you whether {{stu}}'s answer is correct or not. (There may be some tricky fraction algebra here... stick with it, be patient, and simplify as much as you can!)

outtro.p: To see why, remember that if f and g are inverse functions we must have f\bigl(g(x)\bigr) = x and g\bigl(f(x)\bigr) = x.
We can check that {{stu}}'s answer satisfies f\bigl(g(x)\bigr) = \displaystyle {{fog}} and g\bigl(f(x)\bigr) = \displaystyle {{gof}}.

content.p: If {{stu}}'s answer was incorrect: Provide a step-by-step solution with explanations for {{pos}} original problem above.
